job_title: Veterans Certification Specialist in Denver, CO
pros: Work in a Veteran friendly office. Decent facilities. Work on a college campus, many fun things to do. Veteran Culture was largely respected while I was there.
cons: Pay can be lack luster. Managers are career oriented and in some cases that clashes with veteran culture. Some trainings that the university requires can feel like an attack on values Veterans hold. management is career oriented and will not vouch for a veteran that slips up or makes comments that are out of line with the universities policies.

pros: Leadership in the Accounting Department is the best!

pros: Mission driven, strong leadership, focus on students
cons: lower pay than many universities

review_title: Avoid this place unless you like being overworked and underpaid.
pros: Good vacation accrual and friendly people, decent place to start if you are new to the workforce and need to build work experience.
cons: Higher up management claimed they cared, but they consistently lied and told us there was no money for raises in 2020 because of COVID (yet gave themselves $1000's in raises! WOW). While those of us in the trenches making less than $50k were given nothing but a good job! Salary is not competitive because its higher ed so you better love what you do. Siloed work resulted in being overworked and having to deal with burnout for well into the near future. Micromanagement was a huge problem with my supervisor, she was not fit or qualified to lead.

pros: Made really great relationship with people including professors, academic advisors, and peers.
cons: Pay is not crazy good but will get you by.

review_title: One of the 5 lowest funded Universities in the nation. Unsustainable workload.
pros: Teaching at MSU Denver has a direct observable impact on the lives of the students. Many students are first-gen college students, MSU Denver is open enrollment, a Hispanic Serving Institution, and generally has the highest percentage of students of color in Colorado. Some programs are competitive enough regionally that they are top picks for students who could get into a more prestigious University. With the lowest (or close to the lowest) tuition in the state the value for the student is truly remarkable! This is a good place for educators who want to make an impact; focus on teaching (currently at a 4/4 lecture load with roughly an 80% teaching, 10% research, 10% service expectation) ; do not have, or do not desire to have, an R2 or R1 caliber research practice (you can make tenure on a less robust research practice), can survive on the salary (has other sources of income and/or; has a partner with a full time job, doesn't have kids, already lives in the area, or is a home owner relocating from a more expensive housing market.)
cons: As of 2022 Colorado is 49th in the nation in funding higher ed per student. Arizona is 50th – though that is a little bit of a misnomer because ASU has tens of thousands on online students who comparatively cost less per pupil to educate. So, per in person pupil Colorado is probably dead last. MSU Denver, in turn is the lowest funded University in Colorado, thus the headline. It could be the lowest funded University in the US – I wouldn't be surprised. The problem is due to systemic State constitutional issues (google "Tabor amendment") that were passed during Colorado's small-government libertarian heyday and will likely never be fixed. Instead of being ashamed by the dismal state of higher-ed and seeking to rectify it, the current Democratic/Libertarian governor Polis's messaging and actions seek to de-emphasize the value of higher education. This situation is so intractable it has its own term "The Colorado Paradox" which seeks to answer the question of how Colorado is able to maintain a robust economy with such dismal higher ed. The answer is... Educated people from other states continue to move here in droves. What this means: • Non-competitive salaries • Understaffed administrative offices and/or staffed with junior level people. (ex. it routinely takes 4-5 months for HR and Financial Aid to approve a work-study student to begin work.) • Constant exodus of talent and turnover among competent staff • 10% faculty service expectations ballooning to unsustainable levels to make up for staffing shortages • Faculty regularly doing the job staff would do at a different institution; academic advising, tech. support, facilities management • All of this culminating in workload expectations that are not aligned with the salary or the stated goals or values of the institution

pros: You receive 4 weeks of vacation and 4 weeks of sick time, plus holidays which most are moved to the week between Christmas and New Years to give you that time off. You can receive tuition benefits.
cons: Depending on the department, it can be an amazing experience, or a terrible one.

pros: The students are amazing and always go extra mile
cons: The institution's leadership is a revolving door of below average

review_title: Good place to be a professor

job_title: Prior Learning Coordinator in Denver, CO

review_title: Best higher ed Institution in the state
pros: Culture. Everyone is mission-driven. Everyone cares about the students we serve. This is the most diverse workforce I've ever been part of. I don't feel like an outsider for having an unconventional background or personal life.
cons: Some processes and systems are outdated. It can make work challenging.

job_title: Alumni Engagement Coordinator in Denver, CO

pros: There are a lot of great students

review_title: I really cared about being at a University that had its morals in the right place!
job_title: Assistant to the Vice Provost in Denver, CO
pros:
The culture is by far the most important part of MSU Denver, it is what sets it apart from all the other Universities. President Janine Davidson talks all about that on the webpage for the University, but more importantly she enforces it at the campus and in the work environment. 

I am here to study psychology (community based mental health) and have taken a full-time position at the University to take advantage of its awesome educational benefits so that my wife can study psychology with, me which is also covered under my benefits package. With no limitations on time of service we applied and have already been accepted to the program in my first week of full-time employment (wife is taking 12 credits and I am taking 9).

I took classes last year here as well, under my GI bill, and have yet to have a professor that wasn't absolutely amazing (hence me deciding to take a position in the office of the provost). The student body reflects the Universities direction and is equally as welcoming to all who attend. 

The University is rooted in Denver at the intersection of two major highways for easy access and still has on campus parking through AHEC (limited). If you are using city transportation there are multiple bus stops on three sides of the campus and the fourth campus boundary is the light rail with two stops that service the campus.
cons: For some reason the State and Federal government have continually underfunded this university, but at least we have a great and diverse faculty, staff, and student body.

job_title: Assistant Women's Volleyball Coach in Denver, CO
pros: Very supportive campus, mentors, and colleagues. The Head Coach is incredible and runs the program the way that every program should be run, players first mentality.
cons: Pay just can't support for long in the Denver area. Unless you're planning on moving up the coaching ladder, the money and time don't make sense.

pros: The students are nice at MSUDenver. It's a diverse population and the campus is always maintained.
cons:
There are many nice people on the campus. I have been here 15 years and a recent announcement from the current President discusses the bonus stipends all fulltime faculty and staff are receiving soon. Her tone deafness hit home the fact we're much like fast food employees to administration. They expect us to do the majority of teaching entry level classes, but we receive nothing. 

At least Davidson's predecessor sent us signed birthday cards. We received small tokens of appreciation from Dr. Jordan, but most of the time need to know information is forwarded to us by admin who know our worth.

pros: MSU Denver has great people who work in entry level positions and the students are amazing. The student body is very diverse and they are great to work with.
cons: MSU Denver has horrible leadership (i.e. AVP of Student Affairs, Assistant AVP of Student Engagement and Wellness, and more). They do not pay their employees enough, overwork them, and have a culture of favoritism. They say they value DEI, but they don't. Unless you are one of the favorites, you will not move up, and you will not be treated well.

review_title: MSU Denver: an inspiring place to work
pros: Professors get to teach hard-working, motivated students who are committed to moving forward in their lives and careers. (Many of them are the first in their families to go to college, and it is wonderful to see how they give back to their communities after taking their degrees.) There's also more diversity in the student body, faculty, and administration than most schools, which is refreshing. It feels good to teach in a place that is not only concerned with catering to the richest and most privileged, but to anyone who wants to better their life. You also work in the heart of downtown Denver on a lovely campus, right across from the theater district, a short, easy walk from shops, galleries, sporting arenas, and restaurants.
cons: As a newer state university (est. 1965), we do not have the deeper pockets of other, older schools. Our endowments are lower, so incoming salaries and perquisites may be lower.

Pay flexibility may not be a competitive as other university institutions, however, the comprehensive benefits is a great supplement.

review_title: Remember to just show up, work, then go home

Keep the mentality of just keep smiling and nodding your head when people talk to you. Making worker friends? Do not.

pros: I witnessed incredible compassion for students by many faculty. I also saw how hard some faculty and staff worked to establish close connections with students and fostered an atmosphere of support to ensure success. Students were motivated for the most part, and the majority were mature and had already seen how valuable an education would be for them, and acted accordingly. Students were amazing to work with and often wanted to work as hard as faculty wanting to work with students.
cons: Bullying, mobbing, and cult of personality ruled the day. It was hard to see senior faculty bullying junior faculty, chairs threatening faculty, and tenured faculty establish tribes where offending them would be grounds for denying tenure, or worse yet, harassing them into quitting. Chairs would retaliate by taking away employment opportunities, under the excuse of "not enough classes to go around," but when faculty are resigning, how is there not enough to support adjunct faculty? So much money spent on anti-bullying training, but I observed chairs and tenured faculty alike bullying junior, untenured faculty.

pros: Great environment to work at
cons: 24 credit hour teaching load

review_title: Good way to learn while you work
pros: Great environment, coworkers, and easy to make your own schedule as a tutor.
cons: Students sometimes want the world from you.

job_title: Social Media Intern in Denver, CO
pros: Friendly staff dedicated to helping students succeed.
cons: Nothing of consequence. Everything ran smoothly.

review_title: Put good in, get good out.
pros: Working for student government, you are employed by the college and are able to access many of its employee resources (e.g. training, conferences, etc.). It is evident in the work environment that everyone cares about the students of the university. Though there may be differing opinions at times on what is best for the students, I feel that just about everyone I worked with had the mission of the school--to create lifelong learners--in mind. When all else fails, everyone comes back to that.
cons: The student government experienced many unhealthy conflicts during my time there. Some of the leadership was ineffective in creating a cohesive and positive culture. The con in this environment is that unfit people can step into leadership roles, especially when hiring in the legislative, judicial, and upper executive branch occurs in the form of voting, where most of student population base their choices upon the bios, names, and pictures of the candidates. Perhaps a stronger screening and qualification process, evaluating character, work ethic, accomplishments, and authenticity, ought to improve the continuity of quality leaders on MSU Denver's student government.

pros: Student environment, urban setting, modern, multiple education programs and degree types, right across from the Pepsi Center, public transportation
cons: The upper administration of this institution may have the best intentions to support the student population but make no strives toward employee morale thus no strives toward employee retention.  During my time there (less than two years), turnover among non-state classified staff was nearing 25%.  They practice a "shared governance" administration that invites you to participate and address issues at your own peril.  MSU employment of non-state classified employees is at will and supervisors who don't have a clue about what constitutes hostile work environments, team-oriented goals, positive acknowledgment or employee morale are the middleweight hammer who fire at will because they know they can just open another search.  Searches take a very long time also due to so-called "shared governance". It is no wonder that both recruitment and retention are dismal at this institution as HR is inept and finance is corrupt.  I have never seen an EEO office more bent on serving their master than their workers.

review_title: Work here if your primary goal is to make a difference
pros: We work with a lot of first-generation-to-college students.  It's a very diverse and global campus climate.  The faculty are here because they want to teach first, serve second, develop professionally third.  The staff are here because they care about the students.  Emerging excellence in select areas.
cons: Low pay.  Marginal benefits.  One of the most underfunded institutions in the country.  Reputation as one step up from a community college - modified open enrollment.  Employees in some areas have significant fear issues.  No career path for staff members.

job_title: Program Support/BSW Advisor in Denver, CO
pros: Working in higher education has many benefits, particularly if you are seeking Tuition Reimbursement for an advanced degree.  There are also a plethora of organizations you can be a member of as well as adding to your professional background by serving on institutional committees.
cons: It is not uncommon to do the work of more than one person.  That is, although you might have a clearly defined role and scope of work and responsibilities, there simply is so much to do at the department and university level that invariably you take on the work of another position that is not filled.  This is most often the case with state-funded, not-for-profit institutions.

pros: MSU Denver was a fantastic place for me to learn, both educationally, and in gaining real world experience. The IT Department works well with your schedule, and is always willing to help you grow and develop you in order to start your career.
cons:
The atmosphere can be lazy at times. There are a lot of classified workers, so tehey do nothing, get paid way more than I do, and can't get fired. 

It also suffers from inter office politics, preventing a cohesive culture from developing.

pros: There was lots of freedom within the tutor center to do your own work when you had no students asking for help, but often you didn't have to worry about it because you got to help a lot of people! Students start becoming regulars and depend on you. Very flexible with student schedules.
cons: There were some awkward moments when a student I tutored tried to ask me out. You only get hired per semester so if you want to continue working there you pretty much have to reapply every 6 months or so. There is no vacation or sick day but you aren't working full time anyway so it's not a big deal.

review_title: Very little transparency; I don't feel valued
pros: Students are wonderful to work with. Many faculty and staff are also great people. Departments that are well run are brilliant.
cons: People seem to get leadership roles through favoritism or because they've been here forever.  No transparency in management.  The worst people are at the top, and the best are at the bottom.  People are valued differently depending on whose ear they have.  Nobody gets raises ever.

pros: Always changing environment, must be able to think on your feet, interact with many different people, lots of freedom to cover material as long as it fits within the general education guidelines
cons: little or no upward mobility for part-time faculty, limited guidance or support for developing coursework, many hours of prep work outside of class required but not compensated

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Garden Grove, CA
pros: A very good place to start ones career, but use it as a stepping stone. Most of the environment changes quickly so its good for those who like it.
cons: Management do try to keep their employees happy, but does not always work, long hours sometimes and also additional jobs are added to ones role, that the pay does not justify it, its hard enough already to get a raise as its based on the state agency having a budget.

pros: Good mentor-ship, friendly office culture. I am holding a work-study position and my supervisor has been very nice and understanding to me. Everyone in my workplace is always willing to help each other in handling difficult situations. We get to study when it's not busy on the floor. Training meetings are always fun time when we meet all of our peers and have a great time together.
cons: Everyone starts with the same pay rate no matter what degree that person is holding. There is little promoting opportunity or upward mobility in my job.

pros: Working on the Metropolitan State University Campus as a Food Bank Coordinator (in conjunction with the Student Engagement and Wellness Office was such a rewarding experience. I really enjoyed assisting students who needed help and guiding them to other needed resources. My employers in the S.E.W. Office were wonderful! They are so helpful, informative and compassionate. One would be hard-pressed to find better people to work with  and communicate with. I really enjoyed my employment with them.
cons: Nothing to complain about here!

pros: Lots of great people to work with.  Students are really good and interesting. Feels like you can make a difference in the job.
cons: It's all up to who your supervisor is.  If you have a bad one, it's a toxic, stinking mess and you are helpless. Annual reviews are either useless or used to punish. Anti bullying policies confusing and nobody knows where to report.

review_title: SI Leader for Principles of Accounting I
job_title: Supplemental Instruction Leader in Denver, CO
pros: The Supplemental Instruction (SI) program is one of the most flexible and development oriented student part-time positions on campus. It gives you an opportunity to collaborate with other students, create and lead group sessions, experience leading groups in online and face-to-face setting. It is also a great networking place for meeting other successful peers from the university.
cons: Sometimes, I have got a feeling that I am undervalued for my job. I could probably make around $15-30 an hour doing this privately. However, that's where the budget is.

review_title: Good Experience working at Metro State
job_title: Career Counselor/Database Administrator in Denver, CO
pros: The office I worked in was professional and had minimal politics.  Work life balance was equal.  Had some overtime but comp time was available.  it was great working with students and the faculty.
cons: There was a certain amount of politics at the College in general.  The pay was a bit lower than I would have hoped and upward movement was available but you had to wait a bit longer.

review_title: Great school but challenging place to work
pros: Great benefits, decent compensation.  There are lots of good people who do good work.  The mission is compelling -- educating Colorado!
cons: Unfortunately the place is full of bureaucracy.  Some policies simply don't make sense.  The senior management is extremely hierarchical and people work in siloes.  It is also very political and there is little trust.

review_title: good people, yet slow governement pace, change and open-mindedness
job_title: Accounts Payable Specialist in Denver, CO
pros: Great people and experiences with. They care about their employees and feed them well. Though upward growth is minimal.
cons: There is a lack of training materials and narrow-mindedness exists among some ranks. They are missing a general cohesion among departments, making communication and coordination difficult.  Much room for improvement.

review_title: Great people, salaries are not so great
pros: I love the environment, and most people are awesome to work with. It is a great place to get job experience when entering the field after college.  Job security is a big plus.
cons: Pay is not great, about half of what I would make on a private company, so many employees are happy with doing a mediocre job, while others have to pick up the slack.

review_title: Computer Lab Department is a great opportunity for any student concentrating on school while still making some money.
job_title: Service Center Tech in Denver, CO
pros: It's encouraged to work on your assignments if there are not relevant work duties to be handled. Work is not difficult. Flexible scheduling.
cons: They pay could be higher at first, but if you do well - then you may get your raise for the next semester.

review_title: Student Work Study Financial Aid & Scholarships
pros: Learning about how the processes of financial aid and scholarships work, getting to have flexible hours around classes, having some time to work on your studies after your job duties are complete.
cons: Little equality in pay between peers, limited flow of information, common miscommunication, little opportunity to advance, no incentive to do anything above the bare minimum

pros: Working with students in a environment that is always changing. Great for first starting out, getting experience and plenty of opportunities across campus.
cons: Pay is fairly low, especially for teachers. They would do well to invest in their teacher salaries rather than building new office buildings for their admins.

review_title: Great, loved it. Great place to work and go to school.
pros: Awesome work environment, laid back can do your homework on down times is nice.
cons: Management needs to communicate their policies better to it's employees.  The learning curve is a little challenging at first, no benefits, paid holidays or vacations.

pros: Decent pay scale, many little perks, fun to work with students and faculty. Big campus with many opportunities across the board.
cons: Very hard to get pay raises and promotions if you are hired as a classified employee. Management tends to only reward other managers and doesn't consider employees who actually did the work.

review_title: Great Experience as a Work Study/Student Hourly
job_title: Call Center Lead Technician in Denver, CO
pros: Amazing staff to work for, great location, great hours flexibility, great environment, great sociability of the management staff, and exceptionally well kept offices.
cons: The hours that you can get scheduled to work as a work study or student hourly caps at about 30 hours a week, unless you have a specific job that requires more hours.

review_title: One of the worst experiences of my career
pros: Downtown Denver location is great and the College's mission is beyond reproach.
cons: People work in silos, most senior management positions are filled because of political connections, not experience.  This creates a highly political environment rather than a functional workplace.  The president is set on doing what he wants to do despite any input from others.  People praise him as a leader, but he has poor people skills and is racking up debt at an extraordinary rate.

pros: Tuition reimbursement program; generous number of vacation and sick days per year; diverse student population; downtown campus
cons: Heavy workloads, long hours, stressful environment, and high-cost benefits

review_title: Miserable. There is a complete lack of accountability. Very hierarchical.
pros: Some departments are happy. There are some amazing people scattered in but overall, the culture is very negative.  Biggest pro is that Metro really does provide desperately needed higher education to Coloradans and is critical to our economy. There are a lot of amazing professors and exciting initiatives going on.
cons: High turnover, low moral, lack of accountability and transparency. Senior leadership. There is a complete lack of accountability. Very hierarchical. Low moral among administrative staff. Significant turnover, particularly in alumni relations and communications.

pros:
Student body is diverse (across multiple intersections of identity) and eager to get their education.
Lots of leave available
cons:
Leave is hard to take because the workload is high
Lack of resources for departments mean that everyone is working at max capacity always which creates a lot of infighting between otherwise well-natured and passionate people.

pros: A very tight nit group of students within a positive environment. Constantly given support academically, professionally and personally.
cons: Department had too many employees which allowed a good amount of the employees to stand around and contribute nothing to the role.

pros: Working at a University has its advantages, great room for networking, great social aspect. Having the capability to take classes.
cons:
There are some very distasteful and disgusting people that are currently employed.
If you want any aspiration of  NO personal growth, by all means, work here.

pros: I worked here as a student employee and they put my class schedule first while allowing me to change my hours for other jobs. I worked with everyone from almost every department and it felt like I was apart of the team despite being a student employee.
cons: At times there was no work or the work would be redundant.

review_title: It's a great place to work full-time, but affiliate employment is horrible.
job_title: Affiliate Professor of English in Denver, CO
pros: Metro has amazing students and faculty; there is no doubt about that. People who work there are passionate about learning, and there are a lot of opportunities to learn new things and grow, even as an employee.
cons: Affiliates make crappy money, are treated without respect, and have no benefits.

pros: A great way to get experience on your resume. They are accommodating to entry level employees and the training required. Hours were flexible and worked great with my class schedule.
cons: Low pay, often times expecting a lot more than what they were paying for.

job_title: Social Media Intern in Denver, CO
pros: My boss has been incredibly supportive throughout my time here, offering professional development opportunities like resume reviews and conferences to attend.
cons: The student roles are still getting figured out, which can sometimes make the students feel unsure of what they’re supposed to be doing.

pros: Great urban energetic environment, good academic standing
cons: Have to pay to park (up to 6.00/day), have a lot of work to do to perform research responsibilities

review_title: Could be so much more efficient
pros:
Working with excited students that want to learn.
Establish close relationships with various departments in an immersive learning environment.
cons:
Working with students that don't care to learn.
Low pay and red tape makes everything slower.

review_title: I recommend not wasting your time working as an Affiliate professor
pros: A little extra pocket change, teaching experience obtained.
cons: No stability, unpredictable enrollment for classes, no seniority, poor communication and mixed signals from superiors.  Only work here if you like to spend a lot of time prepping, teaching, grading classes for low pay and no job security or paths to advancement. Don't waste your time.

pros: The environment at MSU Denver is very positive and in my experience, everyone's ideas are heard and work flow is consistent. Great work/life balance.
cons: Occasional Office Politics,  Mixed employee types can be frustrating since there are different requirements for classified and administrative staff.

job_title: Research and Development Engineer in Denver, CO
pros: Amazing people work in this office and it offers flexibility but also a true office dedicated to growing future leaders. Consistent training on leadership and opportunities for success.
cons: Hard to get a job in, but worth the effort.

job_title: Work Study Student in Denver, CO
pros: Job allows me to work around my class schedule. Work is not very difficult and sometimes allows me to study while on the clock.
cons: Low pay. Can be boring at times. Only allowed to work an average of 16 hours a week.

pros: Work from home one day a week, this benefit depends on the program director.  Many employees don't have this options.
cons: Very cut throat environment!!  Watch your back.  The jealousy of  female millennials and nursing chair are a problem.  Chair has poor leadership and employee management .

job_title: Assistant to the Assistant Vice President for Curriculum and Academic Effectiveness in Denver, CO
pros: Nice campus, good mission and values
cons: You commit to the work because you really like it and the environment is great. Then after 6 years of stellar reviews and accolades, your position is eliminated and you're out. No idea, no warning. Just out.

pros: I love teaching and working with other students. The responsibilities keep me on my toes and further my skills.
cons: In a period of transition, development of employees who work hard for the organization should be a priority

pros: Had the opportunity to work with a diverse range of students and help them achieve  educational goals.
cons: I feel that the wage should of been higher for the service being provided.

review_title: A wonderful experience for students who enjoy assisting others with meeting education goals.
job_title: Supplemental Instruction Leader in Denver, CO
pros: The most positive and supportive experience I have ever encountered.
cons: The process may seem overwhelming at first, but you will quickly discover how easy it is!

pros: New facilities, great collegiate atmosphere/energy, ERP experience.
cons: Minimal opportunity for advancement or pay, problems that get bubbled up to management are not really acknowledged.

pros: Our students largely represent non-traditional, underserved populations
cons: The salary is low, even for our peer institutions and regional comparison institutions. Cost of living is high in Denver. Cat-I faculty teach 4/4 loads as a minimum (24 c/h per year)

review_title: Lots of work with little support
pros: You get to work with a diverse student population.
cons: As many higher ed places, lots of work with little support at times. More work than one can handle with most positions.

pros: Solid leadership, progressive, diverse, urban setting in a hot market
cons: Not as well-known or respected in the region as should be. Salaries at this state institution are generally quite low.

pros: Strong, fun and collaborative work environment
cons: Low pay, lack of structure that promotes overall improvement of office functions

pros: Had autonomy over my programs. Relaxed environment. I really loved the culture and environment of my department. Got approved to work 4 days a week.
cons: Sometimes the traffic from Denver could be bad

pros: Relax environment and management. Help student gain experience while attending at school. Relevant work experience to put on resume
cons: Not a lot of opportunities for full time position, inconsistent communication between departments.

pros: Flexible hours and understandable when you have class conflicts
cons: Some of the co workers think that they are managers and have bad attitudes

job_title: Computer Lab Technician in Denver, CO
pros: Flexible around class schedule. You're able to study on the job and meet a lot of people.
cons: Can't really think of anything. Pay isn't that great, but what do you expect?

review_title: Great people and opportunity, some politics.
pros: People are there because they want to work there, and generally enjoy what they do.
cons: Power struggles and politics can be present in some departments.

job_title: Field Resource Coordinator in Denver, CO
pros: Great colleagues, amazing students.
cons: Still unsure of how to build it's new brand, leads to lots of changes over in programs

pros: Flexible and accommodating to employee needs. great place to work if you have a family
cons: Pay is low compared to other industries

review_title: MSU Denver is an incredible institution.
job_title: Team Leader New Student Orientation in Denver, CO
pros: Cost, faculty, flexibility in class schedule, small class size.
cons: None, I  had no problems at this school.

pros: Great people.  Everyone is super friendly.  Management is awesome.  Good time off
cons: Excellence is rarely recognized.  To be expected with a state job

pros: Friendly supervisors, coworkers. Schedule can be fitted to your classes schedule.
cons: Have to take classes in order to be a student (non-faculty ) employee

pros: stuff to learn, do get to see some of the cutting edge, do get a say in day to day conduct
cons: a lot of unpaid work

pros: During a pandemic, office hours are extremely easy
cons: It is low pay and I can work only up to 30 hours a week

pros: Nice staff, good administration, students are generally interested in learning.
cons: Pay isn't that great for part-time faculty (as is usually the case)

review_title: A good, part-time opportunity to earn a little extra pocket cash after class.
pros: Laid back environment, incentives, training
cons: Other than cold-calling, not much else bothered me.

pros: Great office environment , great people, experiences, events & involvement.
cons: None, I loved working there!

job_title: Call Center Agent in Denver, CO
pros:
Performance Based Salary Increases
Great Work Environment 
Flexible Hours
cons:
Late Hours
No 8 Hour Shifts

pros: the department  very supportive of faculty
cons: had to walk too far from parking to buildings and between buildings

pros:
Pay good per hour
autonomy to do job
department support
cons:
You will struggle tremendously without additional employment
renewal every semester

pros: The schedule is flexible, the people are nice, and the atmosphere is great.
cons: I have no complaints against working here.

pros: Learned so much and gained so much professional development. Progressive, inclusive university.
cons: I didn't have any negative experiences

pros: Great environment to work in. They have been more than good to me.
cons: I can't think of anything.

pros: good work environment, very supportive management
cons: salary for adjunct faculty is less than one could get in a coffee shop.

pros: Great communication with and from superiors. supportive co-workers and wonderful environment
cons: some issues with academic bureaucracy

job_title: ITS Help Desk Technician in Denver, CO
pros: You learn lots of skills like Azure and Active Directory.
cons: Becomes redundant and customers can sometimes be very rude.

pros: Great staff, updated tech and facilities!
cons: Without a Masters, teaching options are somewhat limited.

job_title: Supplemental Instruction Leader in Denver, CO
pros: As a student employee, they will work around your schedule.
cons: This position offers limited hours and no benefits.

review_title: No one will even know your name!
pros: Interesting student body. Good facilities.
cons: Terrible pay as well as sense of community

pros: Best boss I've ever had, flexible
cons: Not many tasks, besides that everything was great

pros: Positive relationships with faculty and good resources
cons: Expected too much for hours and pay

pros: Flexible schedule, friendly work environment, professional work environment
cons: I don't see any con

pros: Experienced with small group work environment
cons: Worked a lot with students

pros: Great place to learn and work
cons: Learning opportunities, support from professors

pros: Great team to work with.
cons: They don't invest in their faculty.

job_title: Financial Aid Counselor in Denver, CO
pros: Great people and warm atmosphere
cons: can be busy between semesters

pros: Flexible hours, easy going environment
cons: no benefits or personal growth

pros: Great platform for higher education: affordable and accessible.
cons: Glacial processes and highly political office environment.

pros: generally good number of openings, good benefits
cons: Expect well over 40 hours, considerable, widespread back-stabbing, ethically challenged, gender discrimination regarding pay
